background: There are two chemical reactions (A and B) in a laboratory that produce a rare compound using rare inert gas and treated water. There is a limited supply of both inert gas and water available.
constraints: Number of chemical reaction A is non-negative
Number of chemical reaction B is non-negative
Total use of inert gas by reaction A and B does not exceed TotalInertGas units
Total use of treated water by reaction A and B does not exceed TotalWater units
objective: Maximize the amount of rare compound produced from both reactions
description: There are two chemical reactions, chemical reaction A and chemical reaction B. Chemical reaction A requires \param{InertGasA} units of rare inert gas and \param{WaterA} units of treated water to produce \param{CompoundA} units of a rare compound. Chemical reaction B requires \param{InertGasB} units of rare inert gas and \param{WaterB} units of treater water to produce \param{CompoundB} units of a rare compound. There are \param{TotalInertGas} units of the rare inert gas and \param{TotalWater} units of treated water available in the lab. How many reactions of each type should be done to maximize the amount of rare compound produced?

parameters.definition: Amount of rare inert gas required for chemical reaction A
Amount of treated water required for chemical reaction A
Amount of the rare compound produced by chemical reaction A
Amount of rare inert gas required for chemical reaction B
Amount of treated water required for chemical reaction B
Amount of the rare compound produced by chemical reaction B
Total amount of rare inert gas available
Total amount of treated water available
